title: EDITORIAL_ Too much privacy sacrificed
full text:
Aug. 16--Congressman Brett Guthrie's recent defense of the National Security Agency's ability to collect domestic telephone data continues to raise questions on how much privacy U.S. citizens are really sacrificing.
Too much, if you ask us.
Guthrie voted against a House amendment that would've removed the NSA's controversial surveillance powers. The justification for the NSA's snooping is to thwart the threat of terrorism, which has been heightened since the 9/11 attacks.
"If it was unreasonable search and seizure, I'd vote to end it tomorrow," Guthrie said last week during a town hall meeting in Hancock County.
But the issue of privacy isn't just about the trade-off in order to enhance national security.
As a country, we have a privacy problem in general, whether it's involuntary as we've seen with overreaching government agencies or voluntary as we've seen with the arrival of social media.
Facebook and Twitter, for example, are very public but oftentimes treated as no one is watching what words or pictures are being posted. Information we would never divulge in live conversations has suddenly become overly transparent on social media.
And then there are the retail stores that take our personal information without our knowledge.
According to the Associated Press, stores such as Best Buy, J.C. Penney, Home Depot and Bath and Body Works track shoppers by garnering information from driver's licenses every time a product is returned -- supposedly to reduce fraud.
That information is used to create "return profiles" and outsourced to a third party's database.
Companies such as Best Buy disclose on their receipts and signage about its return policy, but not all retailers reveal their tracking system.
Although retailers claim the third-party companies do not share customer data, there's still no way to know who really has access to the information.
Whether it's the NSA or retail stores, they all have their "reasons" for intruding in our lives.
Technology advances have no doubt made gaining access to private information easier and more prevalent.
We give lip service to how much we value our privacy as Americans. But at the same time, we're making many more sacrifices than we realize in deterring terrorism, returning merchandise to retail stores and posting on social media.
When it comes to surrendering our privacy, we've proven in many ways that we have a high tolerance level for it.
But if we treasure our privacy as much as we say, we need to stop decreasing its value.
